reviewText:
The plot? The family of a deceased author refuses to give a biographer authorization to write the author's biography. The biographer travels to Uruguay to try to persuade the family.

This movie deserves five stars because its characters are well developed and because everything was original, in a pleasing way. Or if it was not absolutely original, it at least avoided triteness. For example Omar, who appears to be the main character, turns out to be the least attractive character. But you need to be a discerning judge of character to recognize his faults, or indeed to recognize that he has faults. If you are not careful, you may find yourself thinking he is a typical protagonist, one of the good guys.

Other examples of the movie's avoidance of triteness: no violence, no guns, no spies, no car-chase sequences, no superheroes, no aliens, etc. Only one scene might be called an action sequence, and even it is humble in that respect. Nevertheless, from beginning to end the movie is interesting. The location of the story--Uruguay--is fresh. The cowboys (gauchos?) are different from American cowboys. Even the color of the alcoholic beverage is new, a cherry red.

The cinematography and sound are excellent. The acting seems perfect, though in this regard I am not a perfectionist.

Though I gave you a synopsis of the plot, the story is all about character. Who is right? Who is wrong? Who does the right thing? Who does the wrong thing? Who deserves whom, and who does not deserve whom? Go ahead and ignore the old dictum, "Judge not, or you will be judged." Tear these characters to pieces, and I do not mean the actors and actresses, I mean the characters. Or commend them. Judge them! If you can do that, the movie should earn your appreciation.

A waste of 117 minutes

A self absorbed work of monumental disinterest.

Omar Metwally is just not likeable. Why the women in this movie have any interest in this milksop is beyond me.

I kept looking for some kind of climax to the never ending psycho-babble and finally found it in Omar's splay footed run to his lover's arms. You'll have to wait till the 116th minute but it is a hoot.

Positives:
Interesting concept of how much is the public allowed to know more about the life of, and lives surrounding, a public figure. To what extent does a biographer be permitted to pursue that story.
Excellent location filming; good sets; adequate and at times quite good acting; mostly good script in showing the characters' personalities.

Negatives:
Did not pursue the potential philosophical discussions of the rights of privacy vs. the public interest with any depth and meaning.
A lot of pointless and distracting scenes such as the bathing suit scene; manuscript burning and many more.
The final half hour or so just seemed weak; poorly edited and rushed.

This movie was only released in 10 or so cities so no one saw it.
It is a must have for Anthony Hopkins fans.
The BluRay quality is great and we have a cheap BluRay player!
Enjoy the rich colors of the South American scenery.
Edwina

I won't go into the plot and the faithfulness with which it treats with the details of the book from which it is derived. I have not read the book.

James Ivory does not disappoint. This is a movie which struck so many chords with me. Having visited Buenos Aires and other parts of Argentina a few years ago, I identified with the sense of elegance which the film telegraphed both in terms of the gorgeous scenery and the people that it depicted.  I recall walking in Recoleta and seeing middle aged very well kept women sporting their furs with a casualness which had long been abandoned in cities like New York years ago, in response to the vociferous anti-fur lobby. But then and there I thought Buenos Aires seemed stuck in a time warp slightly out of touch with a reality that the rest of the world had long since embraced.  So too in this movie. Here was a group of people tolerating each other and existing in a world not sustainable anywhere else or in any other context.  The author seeking his approval for execution of his precious biography of a deceased author, had a girl friend, Deirdre, who was almost literally disparaged for being too much of the real world and out of sync with the artifice of the gracious but dated Ocho Rios estate and its well-heeled inhabitants. But it was the navigation of that world with language and costuming that was so elegant and measured, that sets this film and its great cast led by Sir Anthony Hopkins, Laura Linney, Omar Metwally, Charlotte Gainsbourg and Hiroyuki Sanada, apart from the ordinary and the mundane.

This film despite being an ode to an upper class existence that most of us will never experience, confers credibility on it and makes us ordinary folk very much interested in how this all turns out for these sorry bunch of misfits bent on validating each other's existence in this finely wrought but fragile world.

This film is based on a novel by Peter Cameron. I have not read this book, and it seems to me that reading it is a prerequisite to understanding much of the movie, particularly the jumbled conclusion. A young American college professor, Omar Razaghi (Omar Metwally) is under pressure to finish his thesis in order to keep his job. He wants to write a biography of an author, Jules Gund, who committed suicide because he could not finish another novel after his one great success. Gund lived on a huge family ranch, apparently first settled by his parents, in Uruguay, five thousand miles away from Omar's college. Although the ranch is most impressive, it's been a long time since that novel's success and money is tight.

Omar wants to get the authorization of the late author's family before writing the biography. Three people control Jules's estate: his widow, his older brother(Anthony Hopkins), and his mistress. Omar's pushy girlfriend pushes Omar to go to Uruguay to get the coveted approval, even though he has received a letter from Uruguay indicating that the family is not willing to grant authorization. Incredibly, he just shows up at the remote ranch uninvited. He has never met anyone there.

Most of the above surfaces in the first scenes of the film. The film quickly proceeds to flounder. I soon found myself not caring about Omar or his Gund project. This film has some of the blandest acting that I have ever seen. I could imagine director James Ivory telling the actors things like, "Could you tone that down a bit? A little more subdued, please." Laura Linney, however, does add some heat to the mix in her portrayal of the widow, particularly early on. Hopkins has had a long and distinguished career, but his is a tepid role in this film, and his performance is not inspiring.

I suppose the scenery is pretty nice. There are some undeveloped but interesting references to the Gund family's German roots. There is an atmosphere of genteel decay. Some remarkably dull jewels. We learn a little about bee stings. There's a gondola imported all the way from Venice. Omar gets stuck in quicksand (or is it just mud?). He dashes about in the rain. . .

Peter Cameron's elegant, wistful novel THE CITY OF YOUR FINAL DESTINATION has been well transitioned to the screen by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala and director James Ivory: in so many ways this film brings a host of fond memories of all of the films made by the members of Merchant Ivory films. It has the same sense of grace of transporting one culture into another, of examining interpersonal relationships as they are tied to etiquette and tradition and family, and the chances we take in the name of self-fulfillment and love.  It is a mood piece and a delectable offering for the brain.

Omar Razaghi (Omar Metwally) is a postgraduate student and instructor at a Colorado College, living in a tenuous relationship with Deirdre (Alexandra Maria Lara), and delaying his desire to write his PhD thesis -a proposed biography of deceased novelist Jules Gund. He is unhappy with his life, frustrated that his thesis committee will not approve of his dissertation unless he has the family of Jules Gund's permission to write the biography. After a little nudge from a colleague he decides to travel to Uruguay - without Deirdre - to gain permission from the Gund family to proceed.  Deirdre, hurt because Omar wants to go without her, insists that Omar travel to Uruguay: this may his only chance to step out of the life whose rut he is in and move on to higher means.

Omar journeys to Uruguay where he meets the Gund 'family' - Gund's gay brother, Adam (Anthony Hopkins) and his lover of 25 years  Pete (Hiroyuki Sanada); former wife Caroline (Laura Linney); and Arden (Charlotte Gainsbourg), Gund's mistress and mother of Gund's daughter, Portia.  Though greeted with hospitality it is clear that the family, as executors of Gund's estate, refuse to give Omar permission.  Omar is invited to live with the Gund's  until he can make arrangements to return to the US, but the visit is extended, allowing for changes to insert in the family unity as each one slowly agrees to allow Omar to write the biography.  Omar has a fall, is recovered by Arden (Deirdre flies to Uruguay for support but senses the change in Omar's feelings with Arden),  and  during his recovery Omar awakens to what he really wants in life - love, beauty, and the freedom to express himself in all matters.

In the manner of fine story telling, there are excellent moments of passion, and comedy, and a fine dissection of family life in all its permutations.  The cast is uniformly excellent, composed of such a stellar group of actors.  This is a quiet adagio of a film, filled with charm, elegant cinematography by Javier Aguirresarobe, and fine music - both from the classics and from contemporary writing by Jorge Drexler.  This film retains the 'Merchant Ivory': and that says enough!  Grady Harp, August 10

This is the type of movie with few surprises and somewhat laid-back acting, but a film that makes you believe in the importance of the story and the characters. Excellent cinematography and direction. I would have given five stars, but have subtracted one for the totally unnecessary use of the tobacco drug by SO many characters! All movies should be tobacco-free!

I didn't see the point of this movie. Fantastic acting and sets, but other than that a meandering plot full of characters you could care less about.. You know it's bad when you're rooting for separatist rebels to suddenly appear, or at least a serial killer. The final "conclusions" made no sense and certainly didn't justify the previous two hours. Maybe the book had a reason to exist but this movie didn't. And what does the title mean? 99% of the movie take place on a huge estate where you need a horse just to get the mail.

Each character stands out for an individual quirkiness, not offering an excuse or explanation for such. At some point, I guess I expected one. The ending was not to my liking, I would have preferred something different.
A surprisingly good film.  Excellent cast, believable story and satisfying ending, even if predictable.
Great movie
Very good. Really would like to give 4.5
Love it.
Enjoyed each character, the overall story, filming, and the no rush pacing.
Great acting.  I enjoyed it very much..
Fabulous acting, romantic premise, rich atmospheric setting, a feeling of mystery and beauty throughout. A pleasure to watch, esp the work of Laura Linney and Anthony Hopkins.
This movie has wonderful actors in it, but didn't seem to have anything else.
Enjoyed it
It was strange but not bad
What I watched was good but I could not finish it .....
It was one of the best films i've seen in a long time
Waste of time movie
Stole my heart!
A little slow and some characters less well developed than others but worth a try. Setting in Uruguay is a great backdrop.
Great movie, unexpected turns and changes
Enjoyable story with quirky and interesting characters. Fun watch with not too much drama or sorrow. Went well with a glass of Pinot Noir.

Although it was a bit morose,  it was intelligently written and the acting was very convincing, making you feel as if they really were the people they were playing.  Also the country in which it was set made it a bit more intriguing.
Engaging love story with great visuals.
no comment
Wonderful
Kind of slow.  Great actors. Marginal acting. Lame story.
Very good.
Very interesting/
Two of my favorite actors-------Anthony Hopkins and Laura Linney!
Anthony Hopkins, Laura Linney and Charlotte Gainsbourg.. Outstanding acting in a mediocre film in a tired formula of horribly dysfunctional people.
Surprised Hopkins would take on such a dull role.
Such rich characters interwoven in a complicated living arrangement. Actors wonderful.
such a great cast - yet a rubbish film.....
Good

Predictable story full of cliches ,  poor acting of the main character.  Beautiful scenery, underdeveloped characters, unbelievable relationships that are not worked out at all.  Nope, fast forwarded to the end just to see if it ended as it would in Hollywood, and it did.  Then there is a completely happenstance meeting at the end of the movie that doesn't add anything.  Bwah. Not cheese nor fish.

This is one of my favorite Merchant Ivory films.  It was pitch perfect to me.  Some movies are better than the book and this is one of them.  As with all their settings, I fell in love with the house.
Anthony Hopkins incredible performance, as usual !  Laura Linney in a different role: very good !  Great story.
Exquisite adaptaion.  Superb writing, acting, cinematography.  Thank you for this gift.
Kept our attention.
Did

I give it a two, only because of Anthony Hopkins. The story wasn't bad, but they dragged it really looong... Omar's dialog was sooo boring... and it could have been so much better...the last 30 minutes of it are really "painful"...
I love Anthony Hopkins, but thought the story line was a bit confusing with all the flashbacks.
Different and I liked it.
Pretty good. Anthony Hopkins Hopkins has performed much better in other movies.
I have always liked this movie.
Anthony Hopkins and Laura Linny are always incredible ...movie fell short though
Great acting and actors
It was ok. Not what I would expect from Sir Anthony Hopkins

Absolute GARBAGE.  What an Anthony Hopkins 'advertised' SHAM.

Do NOT waste your time.

The City of Your Final Destination is a great movie. I watched it 3 times in a row. Just because I kept finding new aspects in it each time. I will more than likely add it to my favorite movie list that I watch from time to time. I will not give spoilers or plot lines, just what I thought of the movie.  This movie does have many different layers to it.

I had never heard of this movie before so I am very glad that I found it. The human interaction in this film is intriguing.  For my liking, Hopkins could have gotten a little more screen time, but some of my favorite movies of his, he has very little screen time. A perfect example is Silence of the Lambs where he has very little screen time.

Blandullo delivered a fine performance as Omar.

I do recommend this movie.

My reviews are my opinions of the movies I have watched and just my opinion. Everyone is different and could have a different opinion of a movie. How boring would life be if everyone had the same opinion of every movie?

Thank you for taking the time to read my review. Please consider following me here on Amazon for other reviews. Thanks and have a blessed day.

I was able to watch this movie for FREE as part of my Amazon Prime membership.
I love it when I'm still thinking about a movie days/weeks after viewing. It usually means I'll watch it again. Many layers. Great characters.
Why is Laura Linney always in the best films even if her part is not always the best one?  This is a fine and unusual example from the Ivory trio.
This is an excellent "sleeper" movie.  We love Anthony Hopkins and he was his wonderful self in this movie.
Great movie, excellent actors!
An under-rated gem, romantic and atmospheric.
Loved it!
Fun..good acting..good writing
The first movie I have seem where Anthony Hopkins did a poor job. This movie was stupid.
good

Had it been shorter, with good writing and acting, it would still be strangely lacking in some element that I can't quite put my finger on.  I wanted to like this, but it felt very disjointed and weird.
Beautiful visually. Simple story line.
Story never really took off. It was a rather slow start and the characters failed to spark interest.
I thought the movie was very good. Sir Anthony Hopkins played a completely different role than I was used to seeing him play.
Reclusive artists in obscurity, living life as you might expect.
A strange situation. Not entertaining.
Slow
Understated gem from James Ivory; great performances, especially Laura Linney's, and lush, beautiful setting.
Interesting storytelling.  The characters were fascinating.
I was very disappointed  given the cast that  was in it, maybe I expected too much with this cast, but even with some unknowns I don't think it would be any better or any worse.
Opens eyes to life in the other America.
I thought this was a really good movie.
Felt at times it was a little slow going. The relationshios of the characters was interesting.
A very original and Iengaging story. Great acting and sense of place.
great
Good character development. Weak ending
Very good movie.
Was a Bomb
Interesting film.  Enjoyed the performances by Hopkins, et al.  Worth watching.
I expected better of Hopkins. Truly stunk at "gay-face." The other leading actor's performance was melodramatic. Poorly directed, but had potential. At least the scenery was nice.
Pleasant movie
Hopkins is great!
The acting was excellent but the story was not very interesting.  I guess I'm just not interested how the other half lives.
Excellent cast, simple story with a more or less suspected outcome.
Beautiful photography.
don't remember even watching it.

It was okay.  I enjoy watching Anthony Hopkins.
Good movie,  growing pains
Fair to good :)
Interesting character study, even though leisurely paced

I liked it okay.  It was interesting and a little dark, but ended upbeat.
Very entertaining movie. Many strong personalities in it. Better than I thought it would be.
Excellent
Very good actors. Unexpectably good.
Wonderfully done by wonderful actors. Most enjoyable story about the craziness of life and love.

Very well done.  Great performances and production.  If you like a plot with a little more substance and subtly, then you will enjoy this video.  No murder or supermen jumping off buildings and landing unscathed.  Just a nice solid film.  I gave this 5 stars because I consider it better than most of the presentations in this forum.  Of course, Anthony Hopkins anchors the film.  There were no substandard actors or actresses in this and I did not have to fast forward through any of the scenes.
Excellent, have watched it twice
Boring senseless and a waste of time.
Outstanding movie.  Good story and acting.
The characters never really developed. I'll bet the book was bettet...
Wonderful story.

Some very good actors--Anthony  Hopkins, Laura Linney, and Hiroyuki Sanada--totally wasted in a dreary and pointless offering from James Ivory and Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. The script is nonsensical, and Charlotte Gainsbourg and Omar Metwally as the two more-or-less-lovers are a couple of charisma-challenged wet noodles. Gainsbourg in particular turns in a one-note performance so irritating that I wanted to jump through the screen and give her a good slap.

I wonder if the book was this bad?
Excellent
Good movie
really boring why would anyone write this and than make a film out of it. also what were the actors thinking.  I guess they got paid no mater what.

A thoughtful Ivory Production about a family living in a remote location in Uruguay.  The family is severely dysfunctional, however each of its members has his/her individual charm. The movie leaves lingering thoughts of seeking to be true to oneself and choosing paths outside the trodden ones.  I really liked it.
Absolutely loved it.
Wonderful movie.

This is a lovely, many layered story featuring extraordinary actors, including Laura Linney, French actress and singer Charlotte Gainsbourg, and the preeminent Anthony Hopkins as you've never seen him.  The scenery is breathtakingly beautiful. The movie whisks you away. I felt like I'd been on a vacation with marvelous people. If you're looking for a rapid action adventure, you won't find it here; but if you let yourself sink into the movie as it unfolds, I believe you'll love it.
Amazing movie which inspires you to move
Good

This movie is nothing but a man's fantasy.  He goes to an exotic locale, meets a beautiful and gentle woman (read that "weak", she couldn't get out of a gondola on land without help) and stays there forever. I was enchanted by the beauty of the movie in the first hour, but I wasn't expecting our protagonist's strong-willed girlfriend to become the villain of the movie, just because she is strong. After all, she is beautiful, level-headed, caring, and never hurt anyone. This movie embodies what is wrong with literature in general. But hey, men are allowed to dream.
Wonderful acting!  It's nice to watch something intelligent and charming for a change.
Ending a bit of a disappointment.
thanks  great item
JUST OKAY.
Anthony Hopkins always shines.
Outstanding cast and performances.

Like a fine glass of wine....this film is to be savored for its ability to maintain multiple complex story lines while providing lots of room for the viewer to just sit back and enjoy. The scenes are magnificent. All the actors shine. It's a lovely story with a storybook ending.

I don't know how I missed this movie when it came into theaters, but I'm glad I found it now.  Magnificent soundtrack and cinamitography----it is quirky; sad; filled with hope; funny in parts; and a kind of melage of human nature.  I loved it and have watched it more times than I want to admit.  Now with the regular stuff - the DVD was as advertised and packed well for shipment.  I used the most economical shipping price, and despite that, I received it quickly.  Although it was a used item, it was in excellent shape. I am excited and pleased to add The City of Your Final Destination to my collection.

The acting is very good,what more can you ask for: Anthony Hopkins, Laura Linney, and Charlotte Gainsbourg. Although I agree with one reviewer that Charlotte wasn't in enough scenes. The supporting cast is also very good.
Some people might think this movie is too slow; but it laced with humor, underlining tension, and great atmosphere. And it is interesting when a self doubting, near hypochondriac, purporting biographer is thrown into the mix. He ends up being the catalyst for positive change.

Really enjoyed this movie. Bought it because of Hiroyuki Sanada. Have watched him in Helix and wanted to see more. He plays a younger gay man here, lover of Anthony Hopkins. He was fabulous. So was the movie. Loved the musical score. Loved some of the scenes, a man's shoe disappearing into the mud, etc.
Anthony Hopkins makes this film though the other actors were very good.  It's an interesting story shot in a beautiful location.  I would recommend it to most people.
I have several books based in South America and this is one of them.  I have not read it yet, but it will be a good one, I can just tell.

This is a wonderful movie about relationships and how timing can be everything !  Uruguay is now on my list of places to visit !  Suburb acting.  Anthony Hopkins is amazing.  Entire cast is outstanding and heartfelt.  Excellent

Doctoral student Omar Razaghi is set to write a biography of Latin American literary luminary Jules Gund, who died in an apparent suicide. He needs permission from his brother and his widow. So off to Uruguay, to meet the family. This group is quirky and living in a little isolated colony, a hermetic environment where they all stew in their own juices about their relationship to each other and the departed Jules. The group includes his brother, the brother's lover of 25 years, Pete, his widow (played admirably by Laura Linney) and Jules' young mistress and their daughter Portia. Omar must get approval from all three brother, widow, and mistress or the biography will not be authorized. Pushing him all the way is his ambitious girlfriend Dierdre. When Omar falls out of a tree and is stung by some bees and ends up in hospital, the mission takes a left-hand turn. Suddenly, it's not about Jules Gund, but about each person and their innermost desires.

The script is from Peter Cameron's novel and is very good. The acting is of course, top notch with such a cast. This isn't a major story but it makes for a good 2 hours of entertainment and the soundtrack has some beautiful music, including the overture from Bastien and Bastienne, a rare operetta by Mozart.

My wife and I absolutely love the rich textures, relaxed pace, and solidly unique character personalities in the movie.  The script is well adapted, intelligent, insightful in its clarity and simplicity.  Even the subtitles are beautifully scribed.  For example, in one scene you read "horse clopping," pause, "cows lowing," pause, "horse whinnies," pause, "brakes screeching," pause, "door squeaking," drawing your attention to barely audible sounds you may miss merely watching the movement of the characters through a scene.  We often watch movies with the subtitles onscreen, finding that good ones actually add to the experience of the film, helping overcome and balance personal viewing prejudices.

Make no mistake the movie is very slow paced, which I actually find appealing. The characters are all expressed with an almost whisper-like quality, as if to keep their world private and secret.  If you enjoy a relationship movie that has a location or scenery based flavor to it, movies like The American, The River Why, Lantana, and The Shipping News, you'll enjoy The City of Your Final Destination.
Anthony Hopkins at his best! The film makers have been loyal to the orginal book and the cast is outstanding.
A complex tale with great dialogue. The television screen doesn't do the sweeping scenes of the Uruguayan fauna. There several sub plots that are intriguing.

I stumbled upon this film while browsing amazon; I had not heard anything about it.  I was pleasantly surprised at how quickly I connected to the characters and the gorgeous setting. The film really drew me in. The script was engaging and the characters were three dimensional.  I would highly recommend this film.

I became a fan of Charlotte after watching The Science of Sleep. She seems to take roles of people who are stressed-out for one reason or another, a good example being the sister to Kirsten Dunst's character in Melancholia. In this movie, she seems to be at ease, though she had previously been under great stress, and tells the story of it with good effect (like saying "Where would I go?" with this acute pain that says 'nowhere, of course' where she doesn't actually say that, and doesn't have to). Sadly, she is not in so many minutes of the film, but where she is, it is all pure magic that she is so good at.

Its great to know that even after the death of Ismail Merchant, that James Ivory can continue to make great films.  Anthony Hopkins is marvellous in this along with Laura Linney.  Well worth buying, and the Blu-ray transfer is very fine.
It just isn't the best performance from amazing actors. Not intolerable, but my husband fell asleep. The supporting characters carry the film, Anthony, Charlotte & Laura in particular.

Jules Gund only ever wrote one book, called "The Gondola," but it was a big hit. But he committed suicide before he finished his second book. Now Omar Razaghi (Omar Metwally) wants to write his biography. He writes to the executors of his estate, but they refuse their permission. Omar's ambitious girlfriend pressures him into going to Uruguay to talk them into changing their minds.

Gund's brother Adam (Anthony Hopkins) is in favor of the project, as much because it might raise interest in "The Gondola" and they'd make money. They need money. Gund's widow Caroline (Laura Linney) is dead set against it. The third executor is Arden Langdon (Charlotte Gainsbourg), Gund's mistress and the mother of his daughter Portia. She is against it at first, mostly because Caroline is, but eventually comes around.

They all live together on the vast estate that the Gunds inherited from their parents. Adam's lover, Pete, is the manager of the estate and has been pestering Adam to let him make the land profitable. He has plenty of good ideas, but some cash will be needed to make any of it work. So Pete, of course, is with Adam in being in favor of the biography.

It's a story with layer upon layer of emotional depth, and very charming. Just the sort of movie Anthony Hopkins does best.

Personally, I enjoyed this movie, even with all the interpersonal conflicts' depicted throughout the film.  Different, yet thoughtfully done, and well performed.  I recommend this film!

I rate "The City of Your Final Destination..." Four stars!

The acting in this Merchant Ivory film was top notch; particularly Sir Anthony Hopkins. The man has so much talent that his aura permeates any screen portrayal he undertakes, and lends it some class. Laura Linney was superb in her role also. Her portrayal of the virago was extremely subtle. A bravo performance. I absolutely loved to loath her character. All the other actors acted like people in real life. It was superb.

The bandaid.  Maybe I missed something.  But there it was when AH was discusssing something with LL. I  forget what because I was so taken with the bandaid on his forehead.
poor editing
viejomalogato

City of Your Final Destination is a terrific movie. Great acting and a thought provoking message about the choices people make with their lives. It makes the viewer ponder their own life for parallel choices and motives they might be undergoing. I found it to be a movie I wanted to discuss in detail afterward. I love that in a film. It is definitely worth watching if you like intelligent films. Excellent!

There's not much action in this film. It has the feel of a staged production, which isn't necessarily bad. It opens its paneled door and invites you in as a guest at the presumably Uruguayan estate of a deceased author who was a Salinger-like recluse known for the one major book he produced. His wife, his mistress, his brother, and the brother's partner, continue to live on together in their South American Garden of Eden retreat. (How such a large estate can be maintained with so little hired help remains one of the few mysteries of the plot.)

There are some tensions between these people who sometimes seem to exist as out-take chapters from the great man's writings. There is an undercurrent of residual jealousy between the man's lawful wife and his mistress. Some additional disagreement is triggered by the intrusion on the estate of an aspiring young American writer intent on writing the biography of his author-hero. Then a bit more potential bitterness is added to the olio when the young writer's girlfriend arrives from the States to tend to him in the wake of an accident he's suffered - and to derail any budding romance he might be entertaining.

These differences don't generally come to a boil though, or even a simmer. For the most part, the characters remain marinating in their own privileged lives of civilized comfort. Since this is a James Ivory production (the remaining member of the famed Ivory-Merchant team), you know the setting will necessarily be a civilized one.

This movie tries to make a gondola that's housed in an out-building on the estate into a central character. The gondola was imported, at great risk and expense, from Europe by the author's parents. They rescued it as part of their attempt to rescue themselves from the Nazi onslaught in Europe. But the repeatedly invoked image of the gondola in this film sort of falls flat. The script was based on a novel by Peter Cameron, and I sense that the gondola might have been a more integral symbol in the book - a symbol of displacement - a symbol of withdrawal from ordinary use and usefulness - a symbol of risk and removal in order to maintain some sane sense of continuity. But all these possible meanings for the gondola get a bit lost in the necessarily brief 2-hour format of a film. Here the gondola itself comes off more as an intruder in the film - and worse yet, an irrelevancy.

Nevertheless, as a whole, this is a worthwhile watch. The actress Charlotte Gainsbourg is memorable and appealing as the author's gamine mistress. Anthony Hopkins lends his usual note of classicism to his role.

Maybe not much happens in the course of this film. But it will probably linger with you, putting you in a mood of calmer hopefulness that some people, somewhere, might yet prove to be civilized.

I am immensely pleased to have found this film. Many of the performances (Anthony Hopkins, Hiroyuki Sanada, Alexandra Lara, and Laura Linney) were inspired but some (Charlotte Gainsburg) were not. The story is engaging but there were many aspects of the plot that did not make real practical or emotional sense.  The motion of the plot is a bit formulaic. The story drew me in in spite of the gaps, however. The cinematography is lush and beautiful.  I particularly liked the warmth of the relationshiop between Hopkins' and Sanada's characters and the coldness at the heart of both Linney's and Lara's portrayal of their characters. When all is said and done, as E.M. Forster said: "only connect."

Excellent in everyway.

Performances were great all around.

You can't go wrong with anything from Anthony Hopkins

This is one of those movies that's like a big slice of pie, scooped onto your plate for you to enjoy without wondering what was on either side of it.  It gives just enough story as a basis to drop you into a segment of someone else's life.  You see really nothing of what went on before, or what comes after.  You merely see one slice of pie.  And it tastes good.  That's all I ask when I'm served.

I'm often reminded of a quote from Hartley upon viewing films such as this: "The past is a foreign country; they do things differently there."  But instead of "past", I put "the lives of others."  This is one of those films, which presents a situation of characters that are foreign to me.  They don't think like I do; they don't live like I do.  But here and there peeks out a sentiment, or longing, that I have felt, that I can understand.  And I always think this is the best achievement of these kind of films: to present people so completely different from yourself, yet managing to find a string or two to tether you to them.  It isolates the things people have in common, from the kaleidoscopic clutter we surround ourselves with.

The basic plot is merely a "MacGuffin" in Hitchcock terms.  Merely the pretense upon which to hang a story.  A guy wants to write the biography of a deceased author, and travels to Uruguay to get the consent of the trustees of his estate: his brother, his widow, and his mistress.  Then it's virtually nothing but his interactions with them and their world.  Chance circumstances can alter the course of our lives.  In fact, when you're just drifting, it takes the introduction of chance to alter them.  You begin to ponder the idea that one's life is guided by nothing more than a set of chance happenings, be they cataclysmic, or merely gentle nudges.

I liked this film.  It has pretty settings and photography; the acting leaves nothing to be desired; and all else is wonderfully done.  It's a slow film, one which many would consider boring.  One has to definitely like this type of film to enjoy it.

Finally, a movie that didn't have to rely on sex,bloody violence, lots of special effects, supernatural events, nor wild action scenes to tell a good story!!!!
  If that is what it takes to keep your attention, skip this movie.  Instead, it has a believable story of various human relationships, beautiful scenery, rich characters, and clever dialogue.
I love Merchant Ivory and this film was no exception.  I once lived in Ecuador, so I could personally relate to much of it.  The acting is wonderful.
I love this movie! Very moving and real depiction of the lives of artists and poets in a beautiful setting.

Wonderful story about love, fate and the choices we make; I enjoyed the tranquility and softness of this movie, and the music was
mesmerizing. Everyone who watches this film will have a different take on it, but it well worth watching.
I love this movie!  Great acting, great story and beautiful scenery of the Argentine countryside.  I love Argentina!
Wow! Was not expecting this movie to be so awesome. Definitely a movie that appeals to the romantic heart and mind. Excellent acting, well paced and good visuals.
great personality description about people leaving in the past and afraid of looking in the future. great actors.

Seeing another pairing of Anthony Hopkins and James Ivory, I certainly could not pass this one up, and I'm glad I didn't.  Omar Metwally is excellent, as are all the actors.  The characters are well-layered with the exception of the monotonously controlling girlfriend, but there's enough richness in the other characters to provide counter-balance  What this film does its best at displaying is the fracturing of personalities and relationships -- one person knows you as this; another knows you as that; and still another knows you differently from the others -- it takes many people to put together the puzzle of a human life; and their own struggles impact how they see you so that they may not know you as well as they think they do via their tainted view of their own lives and the world.  I noticed some reviewers complained about the pace or that the film doesn't make sense.  Let's just say that if you're familiar with Ivory or Merchant-Ivory productions, you will not go into this expecting explosions, car crashes, lots of skin or profanity.  Ivory's genre has always been character studies and human interaction; and he is a master of his genre.  So if you favor typical American commercial films, you probably will not enjoy this.  Not everything will be tied up with a neat bow at the end, and it is up to you to work out what is in the box.  While this is not my favorite Ivory film, it did not disappoint.
